note: In Finland, cryptocurrencies are considered virtual currencies and are subject to taxation by the Finnish Tax Administration (Vero).
Capital gains from disposing of cryptocurrencies, such as selling, trading, or spending, are taxable events.
A €1,000 tax-free allowance applies to total capital gains from all assets, including cryptocurrencies.
Capital gains up to €30,000 are taxed at a rate of 30%; gains exceeding €30,000 are taxed at 34%.
Losses from cryptocurrency transactions can be offset against other capital gains and carried forward for up to five years.
Income from cryptocurrency activities, such as mining or staking, is considered earned income and is subject to Income Tax.
Income Tax rates in Finland are progressive, reaching up to 44%, depending on the municipality and total income.
Purchasing cryptocurrencies with fiat currency, holding cryptocurrencies, and transferring them between personal wallets are non-taxable events.
Gifts of cryptocurrencies valued under €5,000 are tax-free; however, gifts exceeding this amount may be subject to Gift Tax.
Coins received from hard forks are not considered taxable upon receipt.
Taxpayers are required to report their cryptocurrency gains and losses in their annual tax returns, maintaining detailed records of all transactions.
The Finnish Tax Administration (Vero) has the authority to track cryptocurrency transactions and holdings, especially under EU directives like the Sixth Anti-Money Laundering Directive.
Penalties for failing to report cryptocurrency income can include fines, interest on unpaid taxes, and in severe cases, imprisonment ranging from four months to four years.
It's essential for investors to stay informed about the evolving tax regulations in Finland to ensure accurate reporting and compliance with the law.
